title: May 2021 Grazing Update: Spring Grazing Heights and Paddock Size

tasks.task: Conducting a pasture update and providing grazing management advice.
subtasks: Discussing the appropriate grazing height for third leaf stage grass.
Comparing grazing differences between sheep and cows in the same pasture.
Demonstrating the effect of rest periods on regrowth.
Explaining the importance of vegetative growth and seed head preservation.
Addressing challenges in uniform grazing and the use of high stocking density.
Showing the process of dividing a pasture using temporary fencing.
Demonstrating how to calculate paddock size using animal hours and observation.
Discussing the process of moving sheep with newborn lambs.
Announcing upcoming in-person pasture walks and future web update plans.
Confirming the date and location of the upcoming pasture walk.
Reminding viewers to bring lawn chairs for the in-person event.
Expressing excitement about resuming in-person pasture walks.
Discussing post-pasture walk video plans and timing.
Using paddocks and rotational grazing techniques.
Adjusting grazing units based on pasture growth and animal impact.
Demonstrating how to use temporary fencing for varying pasture sizes.
Implementing high stocking density practices to promote uniform grazing.
Observing animal behavior and adjusting management accordingly.

tasks.task: Communicating and networking within the grazing community.
subtasks: Promoting the Eastern Onistle Grazing Council and encouraging membership.
Sharing resources and information through email and videos.
Planning events and activities for members.
Emphasizing the importance of soil and water conservation.
Highlighting practices like mob grazing and forage bank development.
Addressing wildlife concerns in grazing areas.
Providing examples and solutions for pasture management issues.
Addressing the timing of lambing and pasture adjustments.
Responding to inquiries about fencing and field divisions.
